node.text:
Guys like Wali, Afghan commandos, have spent their lives fighting for Afghanistan. They've stood side-by-side with their American counterparts in support of freedom and individual liberties. Now they're out there again fighting for their lives, and our hearts break for the unimaginable losses that have already been sustained. We're happy that Wali and a few others have made it here to the United States, and we hope that more will find a way.

@wtasleem

node.title: It’s Who We Are: Wali Tasleem

node.text:
It's the 77th anniversary of D-Day, where we reflect upon what was lost and what was gained during that fateful time in history. We all ought remember the sacrifices made and ask ourselves: how do we measure up to that? How do we make the efforts of those heroic men worth it?

@coffeeordiemag

node.text:
Today we remember those lost on that day:
U.S. Air Force Technical Sergeant John A. Chapman
⁣
Navy SEAL Petty Officer 1st Class Neil “Fifi” C. Roberts⁣
⁣
Air Force Pararescueman Senior Airman Jason D. Cunningham⁣
⁣
160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (SOAR) Sergeant Philip “Spytech” Svitak⁣
⁣
Corporal Matthew A. Commons⁣
⁣
Sergeant Bradley S. Crose⁣
⁣
Specialist Marc A. Anderson⁣
Two Medals of Honor were awarded for actions taken that day, one to Air Force Combat Controller Tech. Sgt John A. Chapman (posthumously) and the other to Senior Chief Special Warfare Operator Britt K. Slabinski. Our guys at @coffeeordiemag had the distinct honor of speaking to one of the Rangers who fought on "Roberts Ridge" — check out the link in their bio (or head to our stories) to read the whole thing.

node.text:
Yippee Ki Yay, Coffee Drinkers!!

@richardryan is BACK with the merry gift of @mat_best_official and @jtarticle15 and a whole slew of Christmas movies (Die Hard is... I mean, do we even have to say it at this point?) — including one film that's on the horizon.

node.title: If Veterans Were in Horror Movies Pt. 3

node.text:
"I think we're going to find ways to continue to get people out, and this is very much not over on the 31st." There will be more that we can do as time goes on. Remember that as some of these Afghan refugees arrive at their new home in the United States, and remember it as we continue to look for ways out of Afghanistan for those who showed us undying loyalty on the battlefield over the last two decades of war.

Jariko Denman (@laidbackberserker) is a former Army Ranger with 15 combat deployments under his belt, and he was on the ground in Kabul; he left just moments before the explosion that took the lives of 13 American service members and scores of Afghan people trying to get to safety. Jariko was working with Ark Salus in the evacuation efforts, and he wrote what he saw for tag-coffeeordiemag in a few articles. Head over there and check it out, his perspective is raw and unfiltered and unlike many other reports we've been seeing.

node.text:
Our hearts are heavy. The United States lost 13 of some of the finest it had to offer. There is a lot of work to be done, but first we have to stop and remember. Take a minute to look at these names, look them up, read about their lives.

Never forget.

Lance Cpl. David Lee Espinoza, USMC | Laredo, TX
Navy Corpsman Maxton Soviak, US Navy | Berlin Heights, OH
Lance Cpl. Rylee McCollum, USMC | Bondurant, WY
Lance Cpl. Jared Schmitz, USMC | Wentzville, MO
Lance Cpl. Kareem Nikoui, USMC | Norco, CA
Cpl. Hunter Lopez, USMC | Indio, CA
Cpl. Humberto Sanchez, USMC | Logansport, IN
Staff Sgt. Ryan Knauss, US Army | Knoxville, TN
Cpl. Dylan Merola, USMC | Rancho Cucamonga, CA
Sgt. Johanny Rosario, USMC | Lawrence, MA
Cpl. Daegan William-Tyeler Page, USMC | Omaha, NE
Sgt. Nicole Gee, USMC | Roseville, CA
Staff Sgt. Taylor Hoover, USMC | Salt Lake City, UT

node.text:
Edit: New reports are saying that the fallen service members include 10 Marines, 2 soldiers, and a Navy Corpsman. We will keep you updated as the facts become clear.

Details are still coming in, so expect these numbers to change as the situation develops. Our hearts break for those who were killed in action — these are the best our country has to offer. May they rest in peace. Semper Fi.

For live updates, head over to @coffeeordiemag. There is a lot you can do, and how you can help will become more apparent as time goes on. However, the first step in all that is to stay informed. Seek out the truth wherever you can.

If you're completely disgusted by how this is all going down, we can't stress enough how important it is to write and/or call your elected officials. Let them know that none of this is okay. Rally others to do the same. Make yourself heard in a way that matters beyond a comment or two on Instagram.

node.text: This dude has a chill factor of about 9000 🤙

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 24, 2021 tagging @aaronandarcher. May be a cartoon of text.

node.text:
Would you watch this movie?? 🤔 How would this epic action flick go down? Drop your plot ideas in the comments.

We'll go first: In an unspeakable, post-apocalyptic future where coffee is banned worldwide, our rugged hero @aaronandarcher discovers a secret stash of 300 RTDs, hoarded by the caffeine-hungry villain. Archer's mission is to find the coffee and GET IT BACK TO THE PEOPLE.

Also SWIPE LEFT to peep our upcoming FUR MISSILE coffee. It's coming VERY soon and will only be a limited run, so y'all had better keep an ear to the ground. 👀

@dogsofblackrifle

node.text:
"In order for them to stay and fight, they need their families to get out of Afghanistan. They need to know that their families won’t be kidnapped and used as leverage to force their surrender. This tactic — threatening the families of soldiers — may well be one of the reasons the Taliban advanced so quickly across Afghanistan. But someone needs to get their families out.

"This is why Ark Salus, an American nongovernmental organization, launched Operation On Wings of Eagles."

If you want more information, head over to @coffeeordiemag and read about the organization and how they aim to affect real change.

#warinafghanistan
#afghanistan
#brccgives
@laidbackberserker

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, crowd and text that says 'The situation in Afghanistan is heartbreaking. But there's a way you can help.'.

Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'As the country collapses into Taliban rule, those who supported the United States are struggling for their lives.'.

Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, outdoors and text that says 'DO CRMMANDO Among them stand the elite Afghan special operations warriors, many of whom are still fighting right now.'.

Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, military uniform, outdoors and text that says 'Many are being targeted because of the damage to the Taliban they have inflicted over the years.'.
Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing, outdoors and text that says 'It's easy to feel helpless, all the way around the world in our relative comfort. But you can help.'.
Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Ark Salus is an American NGO dedicated to supporting Afghan warriors fighting the Taliban.'.

Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing, mountain and text that says 'They seek to immediately evacuate Afghan SOF families to temporary safe harbors before moving them to longer-term locations as they apply for refugee status.'.

Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, outdoors and text that says 'This will enable those elite warriors to fight without the fear that their families will be leveraged against them.'.
Photo by Black Rifle Coffee Company on August 17, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text.

node.text:
A lot is happening in Afghanistan, but it can be hard to put faces to the numbers you see blasted on TV and across social media. Like Wali, the people over there are real human beings with families and loved ones, and their fate hangs in the balance. Watch Wali's personal story on YouTube or on our IGTV.

@wtasleem
